projects.name: A New User Interface Concept for ATM’s to Reduce Receipt Wastage

content.title: Overview
content.body: We've all used ATMs at some point in our lives. Most of the time, we find that the garbage cans at ATM locations are overflowing with meaningless receipts that consumers have requested. That is what inspired me to work on this design project. As a result, I created a completely new user interface that would limit the amount of unnecessary receipts issued. An experiment was carried out to validate the design. This experiment concluded that by using this design, we can reduce receipt wastage by roughly 50%. This is a huge benefit because we are simply changing the interface to reduce this amount, which means there is no additional expense to execute this design, making this solution incredibly scalable, sustainable, and low risk.

content.title: Process
content.body: The initial step in this project was to consider how I would change the current interface such that it would encourage the user to skip the receipt rather than printing it, when they do not require it. To achieve this I replaced the 'Yes/No' interface with an interface which makes use of Fitts' and von Restroff's laws. After that, I ran an experiment to validate the design. This experiment involved 153 participants and according to the findings of this experiment, we can reduce receipt printing by roughly 50%.

content.title: Accomplishments
content.body: I competed in two competitions: the 'Stanford Design Challenge' organized by the Stanford University in the United States and the 'IET 150 & Beyond' hosted by the Sri Lankan IET Young Professionals chapter. Despite failing to reach the finals of the first competition, I was able to win the second competition by successfully utilizing the feedback I received.

projects.name: International Roughness Index (IRI) Calculation of Sri Lankan Roads Using Crowdsourcing Techniques
projects.role: Mobile Application Developer and UI/UX Designer

overview.title: My Role
overview.body: Mobile Application Developer and UI/UX Designer

content.title: Overview
content.body: A well-maintained road network is an important component of long-term urban development of a country. Researchers have proposed smartphone-based crowdsourced applications as a low-cost effective approach to obtaining frequent road surface quality updates over the last few years. The values show large fluctuations over the conditions under which the road data was collected, which is one of the key drawbacks of these applications. Through this project, we created a road roughness monitoring platform based on passenger cars that can generate reliable findings while minimizing the impact of variables such as car type, smartphone model, or location. Among the features of the created system include automatic travel detection, the ability to use any smartphone in any location with or without an active internet connection, combining information from various sources, and viewing them on a virtual map. This study also proposes a complete system to identify and classify road anomalies from crowd-sensed smartphone data adjusting to different vehicle speeds and other characteristics. A set of field tests were carried out to evaluate the proposed system and the results show that the proposed solution is effective in predicting accurate International Roughness Index (IRI) values and road anomalies after reducing the effect of these varying factors.

content.title: Process
content.body: As the first step, we had to design a mobile application for gathering traffic data. To generate ideas for this, we examined previous map-based mobile applications. Next, we created a prototype of the mobile application, starting with some wireframes. Afterwards, we used Android to develop the application. While this is phase is moving on, the machine learning model to calculate the IRI value was also been developed as well. We conducted testing on the mobile application and made adjustments based on the results. Due to resource constraints, we were only able to perform a few basic user tests of the application. Following that phase, we developed the web application to display the results. While I primarily focused on developing the mobile application, my partner took the lead in developing the majority of the web dashboard and the machine learning model.

content.title: Challenges Faced
content.body: During the project, we encountered several challenges. The first hurdle was the insufficient amount of data available for training the machine learning model. To address this challenge, we employed appropriate pre-processing techniques and, when feasible, applied fuzzy logic inference. Another problem was that the initial version of the mobile application significantly drained the user's battery. To mitigate this, we reduced the rate of data collection through the mobile application. While there were numerous other challenges along the way, we effectively tackled them and managed to complete the project within the specified time frame.

content.title: Accomplishments
content.body: Based on this project, we submitted two research papers. The first is to the 'International Journal of Intelligent Transportation System Research', with the title 'Measuring Road Roughness through Crowdsourcing while Minimizing the Conditional Effects' The other is titled 'Identification of Road Surface Anomalies Using Crowdsourced Smartphone Sensor Data' and is presented at ICTer 2022. We also took part in the Stanford University, USA, Longevity Design Challenge.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Organic Chemistry Conversions is a smartphone game designed to improve the organic chemistry skills of college students. This engaging game comprises 100 levels, each challenging the players to drag and drop the appropriate chemicals into corresponding slots. Successful combinations unlock the next level, allowing players to enjoy the game while improving their knowledge.

content.title: Process
content.body: Starting on this project, I began by analysing the user interface (UI) and user experience (UX) of popular level-based games such as Angry Birds, gathering insights into the design landscape. Subsequently, I created a paper wireframe as an initial conceptual representation of the game's interface. I then translated this wireframe into a digital prototype using Figma. Yellow was selected as the primary colour because of its representation of inventiveness, a crucial asset for students tackling organic chemistry problems. Following stakeholder presentations, the prototype transitioned to the development phase.

content.title: Challenges Faced
content.body: A main challenge I encountered was stepping into the realm of game development for the first time. This new experience required a comprehensive preliminary study. I delved into the intricacies of game creation, examining development processes and the essential considerations a designer must weigh while shaping a game.

content.title: Accomplishments
content.body: While certain constraints limited our application's launch exclusively to Android users, the outcome was better than expected. The application got exceptional reviews, achieving a rating of 4.6/5.0 with over 1,000 downloads in the Google Play store in a relatively brief span. These accomplishments were attained with minimal marketing efforts, emphasizing the application's appeal and impact.

projects.name: Redesign of Asgardeo Homepage and User Registration Flow

content.title: Overview
content.body: During my time at WSO2 I got the oppurtunity to work on the redesign of the Asgardeo homepage and user registration flow. The goal of this project was to improve the user experience and make it easier for users to sign up and start using the platform.

body.body: Before starting the design process, I conducted user research to understand the needs and pain points of our users. To do that I first create a set of personas and then conducted surveys and interviews with users to gather feedback on the current homepage and user registration flow.

After gathering the feedback, I created a set of user journeys to visualize the user flow and identify areas for improvement. Other than that I also created a set of user stories to understand the user needs and goals.

To create a design that resonates with our users, I conducted visual research to understand the current design trends and what our users are interested in. I created a mood board to gather inspiration and then created a set of design concepts to test different design directions.
After that I also researched the competitors to understand their design and user experience. This helped me to identify areas where we could differentiate ourselves and create a unique design.
Then I created an information architecture to organize the content and functionality of the website. This helped me to create a clear and intuitive navigation and layout.
Finally, I created a site map to visualize the structure of the website and ensure that all the pages were connected and accessible.

I used Excalidraw to create wireframes, mainly due to its simplicity and ease of use. It allows me to quickly sketch out ideas and concepts, making it an invaluable tool for brainstorming and collaboration.

I used Figma to create a high-fidelity prototype of the website. The prototype was used to test the usability of the website and to gather feedback from the stakeholders. Few sample of the prototype are shown below.

projects.name: Automated Categorization of Privacy Policies Based on User Perspective
projects.role: Mobile Application Developer and UI/UX Designer

overview.title: My Role
overview.body: Mobile Application Developer and UI/UX Designer

content.title: Overview
content.body: Data privacy deals with the sensitive information of individuals and has become a major topic in modern society. keyhough the practicality of mobile apps has become an essential part of the routines of all most everyone. Consumers are increasingly concerned about their data privacy. Most of the time, these privacy policies that are used to collect and share data that are lengthy and complex to understand. Therefore, a common user finds it hard to understand before agreeing to the privacy policy terms. This project propose an approach to convey privacy policies in a way that a common user can comprehend.

content.title: Process
content.body: First, we conducted a few interviews with industry professionals to gain a better understanding of the problem at hand and to generate suggestions for categorising privacy policies so that users may better comprehend them better. Then, using the information gathered from the interviews and research papers, we developed the ten categories. Following that, we created a chat bot mobile application so that consumers could communicate with the bot about their privacy concerns. For example, if a user wants to know a company's data reservation policy, they may easily communicate with that bot and obtain such information.

content.title: Challenges Faced
content.body: The main challenge we faced was holding the interview sessions because I was still in my third year of university at the time and the professionals who came to the interviews had vast knowledge and expertise in the industry. We overcame this obstacle by working together and correctly preparing the interview sessions. Personally this was a huge experience for me.

content.title: Accomplishments
content.body: Based on this study, we were able to successfully submit a research paper titled ‘Automated Categorization of Privacy Policies Based on User Perspective’ to the IEEE ICIAfS 2021: Information and Automation for Sustainability 2021.

title: Bubble Detector Mobile Application
CS 4472 Mobile Computing - Project
Oct 2021 - Dec 2021
content.body: As part of the 'CS 4472 Mobile Computing' module, I contributed to the 'Bubble Detector Mobile Application' project, aimed at replacing less secure methods of store entry logging during the COVID-19 pandemic with a safer and more efficient solution. Through a mobile application, we introduced a modern approach to mitigate hekeyh risks, eliminating the need for manual entry or QR code scanning. Leveraging Figma for design, Flutter for development, and Firebase for data management, we successfully developed a user-friendly and contactless system that not only enhances safety measures but also showcases the potential of technology to address real-world challenges effectively. This project not only advanced my technical proficiency but also deepened my understanding of technology's role in promoting public hekeyh in unprecedented circumstances.
